item.title: Sunak faces mounting pressure from Tory right over Rwanda bill as deputy party chairmen join rebellion
item.content:encoded:
Lee Anderson and Brendan Clarke-Smith defy the PM by signalling they will support amendments to controversial legislation on Tuesday

Lee Anderson and Brendan Clarke-Smith defy the PM by signalling they will support amendments to controversial legislation on Tuesday

item.title: Cleverly moves to ban Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir as terror organisation
item.content:encoded: <div> The proposal has to be debated and is subject to Parliament backing. <div> The proposal has to be debated and is subject to Parliament backing.

item.title: Sunak suffers blow as two Tory deputy chairmen vow to rebel over Rwanda Bill
item.content:encoded: <div> The Prime Minister is preparing to face down a rebellion of more than 60 right-wingers who want the Bill toughened up. <div> The Prime Minister is preparing to face down a rebellion of more than 60 right-wingers who want the Bill toughened up.

item.title: Livestock export ban makes progress despite N Ireland ‘loophole’ fear
item.content:encoded: <div> The Animal Welfare (Livestock Exports) Bill applies to cattle, sheep, goats, pigs and horses. <div> The Animal Welfare (Livestock Exports) Bill applies to cattle, sheep, goats, pigs and horses.

item.title: Tory MPs told to ignore dire polling amid warnings of election wipeout
item.content:encoded: The party’s elections guru Isaac Levido said the survey was timed to undermine Rishi Sunak.

item.title: Rishi Sunak accused of using ‘Islamophobic trope’ in the Commons
item.content:encoded: Labour MP Naz Shah said it was a ‘painful blow’ by the Prime Minister and called on him to apologise.

item.title: Young people may be missing out because of home working, says Gillian Keegan
item.content:encoded: Young workers want to be going into the office but they report there is ‘virtually nobody there’, the Education Secretary said.

item.title: Sunak: It was necessary to strike Houthis at speed rather than recall Parliament
item.content:encoded: Opposition MPs sought further details on the Prime Minister’s long-term strategy, amid escalation fears.

item.title: Who are Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir which the Home Secretary plans to ban?
item.content:encoded: An order will be put before Parliament which would make joining the organisation illegal in the UK under terror laws, the Home Office said.

item.title: UK will ‘back words with actions’ in Red Sea, says Sunak as attacks continue
item.content:encoded: The Prime Minister’s statement in the Commons came shortly after a missile struck a US-owned ship off the coast of Yemen.

item.title: Shapps makes case for increased western defence spending in ‘pre-war’ era
item.content:encoded: Defence Secretary Grant Shapps highlighted the risks posed by Russia, China, Iran and North Korea.

item.title: Labour suspends London by-election candidate who said 'trans women are not female' after transphobia complaint
item.content:encoded: The accusations are believed to relate to tweets that Laura Pascal posted in July in which she said 'trans women are not female. By definition they are male'

item.title: US trade ship 'hit by missile' off Yemen coast despite Allied airstrikes on Houthi rebels, say maritime chiefs
item.content:encoded: UK Maritime and Trade Operations advises other vessels to proceed with caution in the area

item.title: James Cleverly sidesteps calls to reveal details of missing asylum seekers
item.content:encoded: Labour accused the Home Secretary of appearing to ‘have lost thousands of people’ and failing to get a grip of the issue.

item.title: Missile hits ship off Yemen as ministers face questions over new air strikes
item.content:encoded: Rishi Sunak is due to give a statement on the joint UK-US action last week designed to curtail Houthi attacks in the Red Sea.

item.title: Who is Sir Ed Davey? Lib Dem leader facing calls to quit over Post Office scandal
item.content:encoded: Sir Ed has been criticised for refusing to meet whistle-blower Alan Bates

item.title: Rishi Sunak facing growing pressure from Tory right to toughen Rwanda Bill
item.content:encoded: It has emerged that Kemi Badenoch privately warned that the legislation needs strengthening and Lee Anderson considered rebelling.

item.title: Hizb ut-Tahrir: Islamist group that urged chants of jihad on streets of London to be banned
item.content:encoded: Expressing support for, or being a member of Hizb ut-Tahrir will become a criminal offence punishable by up to 14 years in prison

item.title: Sunak plays down dire poll figures amid warnings of election wipeout
item.content:encoded: A major opinion poll indicated Labour could be on course for a 120-seat majority in the election expected later this year.

item.title: Lewis Goodall on when we'll actually get to elect a Prime Minister
item.content:encoded: The News Agents podcaster knows exactly when

item.title: Sunak ‘will not hesitate’ to protect UK security after Red Sea strikes
item.content:encoded: It comes after Defence Secretary Grant Shapps refused to rule out further military action to repel Houthi assaults on cargo ships.

item.title: Sunak hits out at political ‘smears’ over his wealth
item.content:encoded: The Prime Minister, who with his wife Akshata Murty has an estimated net worth of £529 million, is one of the richest men to ever enter Number 10.

item.title: Prime Minister takes questions and visits seafood factory on coastal visit
item.content:encoded: Home Secretary James Cleverly was in the audience, along with members of the public.

item.title: Hamas hostage families issue cry for freedom as new exhibition opens
item.content:encoded: The Voices from the Tunnels exhibition displays what conditions were like in captivity based on the accounts of former hostages.

item.title: Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey facing fresh calls to quit over Post Office scandal
item.content:encoded: Sir Ed's failed first test of leadership, say critics as he faces challenge from ex-postmistress

item.title: Junior doctors in Wales stage 72-hour walkout over pay
item.content:encoded: The strike, which began at 7am on Monday and will last until 7am on Thursday, could see more than 3,000 doctors taking industrial action.

item.title: UK to ‘consider’ whether further Red Sea action needed, says Defence Secretary
item.content:encoded: Grant Shapps said Britain and its American allies will ‘wait and see’ whether air strikes have helped to repel Houthi assaults on cargo ships.

item.title: Senior Tory warns party faces 'destruction' as Rishi Sunak under spiralling pressure to toughen up Rwanda Bill
item.content:encoded: Opinion poll suggests Conservatives facing 1997-style electoral wipeout that would hand Labour 120-seat majority

item.title: Shapps insists Sunak can turn round Tory fortunes despite dire poll warnings
item.content:encoded: Defence Secretary Grant Shapps said the Prime Minister’s party had a plan that was ‘starting to work’.

item.title: Conservatives face 1997-style electoral wipeout, major poll suggests
item.content:encoded: A YouGov survey of 14,000 people indicates Labour could be on course for a 120-seat majority.

item.title: 'Woeful' Windrush compensation scheme must move faster, campaigners urge
item.content:encoded: There are 'unacceptable' delays to payouts, a campaign backed by Baroness Doreen Lawrence and Annie Lennox says

item.title: Parents 'in complete chaos' trying to access Government's new childcare scheme
item.content:encoded: Eligible parents of two-year-olds say they are 'being sent on a wild goose chase'

item.title: UK to send 20,000 troops to largest Nato exercise since the Cold War
item.content:encoded: Defence Secretary Grant Shapps will announce the deployment to provide ‘vital reassurance against the Putin menace’

item.title: Fully digital disability work grants system to launch in April, minister says
item.content:encoded: Access to Work grants help people with disabilities or health conditions to get practical support, including special equipment, to help them work.

item.title: Calls for alpacas and llamas to be included in export-for-slaughter ban
item.content:encoded: The Government has said there is no evidence these animals or deer are being exported for slaughter.

item.title: Five people dead after attempting English Channel crossing
item.content:encoded: The incident happened near Wimereux in northern France at about 2am on Sunday.

item.title: Suella Braverman joins thousands at London rally ‘in solidarity with Israel’
item.content:encoded: She chanted with the crowd, took pictures with members of the public and was thanked by others for going to the rally in Trafalgar Square.

item.title: Sunak faces pressure to toughen Rwanda Bill from Badenoch and Anderson
item.content:encoded: The Prime Minister is facing crunch votes on his flagship asylum legislation this week.
